title.value: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions
title.justification: The title clearly encapsulates the core idea of the paper, which is ensuring energy sufficiency using Control Barrier Functions in unknown environments.
title.quote: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions

extractions.description: The paper presents a framework based on Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) to ensure energy sufficiency of robots navigating unknown and unstructured environments. The framework can be integrated with various path planners, including those used for exploration missions. It guarantees that robots will not run out of energy during their missions, validated through both simulation and real-world experiments.

type.justification: The paper includes simulations and real-world experiments to validate the proposed approach, indicating it is an empirical study.
type.quote: We present results using a physics-based robot simulator, as well as with real robots with a full localization and mapping stack to show the validity of our approach.

name.justification: The research focuses on energy sufficiency for battery-powered robot systems, which falls under the field of robotics.
name.quote: Maintaining energy sufficiency of a battery-powered robot system is essential for long-term missions.

name.justification: The research specifically addresses the problem of ensuring energy sufficiency for robots in various mission environments, making it a study in the sub-field of energy management within robotics.
name.quote: This capability should be flexible enough to deal with different types of environment and a wide range of missions, while constantly guaranteeing that the robot does not run out of energy.

name.justification: The GBPlanner is referenced as one of the exploration planners used in the framework.
name.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners exist in the literature, many of which were developed within the scope of the DARPA SubTerranean Challenge (DARPA 2018): the Graph-Based exploration planner (GBPlanner, Dang et al. 2019).

name.justification: This planner is mentioned as another method used for exploration planning.
It is one of the models used in the scope of exploration planning in the paper.
name.quote: the Dual-Stage Viewpoint Planner (Zhu et al. 2021).

name.justification: CBFs are the core model introduced in the paper for ensuring energy sufficiency.
name.quote: Control Barrier Function (CBF) (Ames et al. 2019) to guarantee energy sufficiency when applied alongside an arbitrary exploration planner.

name.justification: Referenced as another exploration planner used.
name.quote: the motion primitives-based planner (MbPlanner, Dharmadhikari et al. 2020)

name.justification: Referenced as another planner within the scope of the DARPA challenge.
Buzz is used as part of the simulation setup.
name.quote: Our proposed framework is implemented as a Buzz (Pinciroli and Beltrame 2016) script that periodically queries the exploration planner for a path and applies the required control commands to the robot.

name.justification: ROS is mentioned in the context of the experimental implementation on the hardware.
name.quote: Unlike the simulation, the rover performs a full-stack 3D localization and mapping using a variant of LVI SAM (Shan et al. 2021) with a frontend generating pose graphs and a back-end performing map optimization.
